topics.body:
"@Virgil Stormblade":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/559e787063687268e900115c#post_559e787063687268e900115c
[bq="Virgil Stormblade"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/559e776363687228250001b9#post_559e776363687228250001b9
I'll still call them raptors anyway. And I hope to God, no other dinosaur film will put feathers on the raptors.
[/bq]
In a decade or so chances are they'll start putting feathers on dinosaurs because when you get down to it the reason why jurassic park dinosaurs didn't have feathers was because our understanding of dinosaurs was lacking back in 1993.

In say a decade or so because kids are growing up knowing that dinosaurs have feathers if they continue to make jurrasic park movies they'll have to put feathers on them eventually because what will happen eventually is kids will start going "why does this movie say it's about dinosaurs when the dinosaurs look like mutant reptiles and not have any feathers?  I'm not going to watch that!  That movie looks shitty!" and thus movies will eventually be forced to put feathers on their dinosaurs.

topics.body:
"@Too_Offensive":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/559e7ae66368720cb90005ab#post_559e7ae66368720cb90005ab
No offense, but the phrase "too ingrained in pop culture at this point" is a massive asspull that people tend to do.

I obviously don't mean say 1 year from now they'll start putting feathers on dinosaurs, but on the flip side saying that they'll forever not put feathers on them even if we're talking 999,999,999 AD isn't really sound.


My guess is that say Jurassic World 3 they'll probably have feathers on dinosaurs.

And how come none of the other scientists ever thought that was stupid to begin with? And they included [spoiler]CHAMELEON DNA AND HUMAN DNA[/spoiler] in the I.Rex!! Might as well slap a sign that says "We really should die right now!"
